WOW. I'm really impressed with seriousness you approached to
acceptance tes=
ting.

On the other hand it seems that much work was involved to make this
=
acceptance framework work fine.

I would like to make our Selenium tests wo=
rk automatically from CI
server (linux server without X), as any JUnit test=
 would work. This
way our Product Owner (yes, we're Scrumming) could write =
all necessary
acceptance tests instead of descriptive acceptance criteria.
=

CI is executing "mvn clean install" periodically and it would be great
if =
we could automate this process.

Any ideas?

Thanks,
Marko
 
--- In junit@y=
ahoogroups.com, Fredrik Wendt <fredrik@...> wrote:
>
> On fre, 2009-02-20 a=
t 13:25 +0000, majkic@... wrote:
> > Hi guys,
> > I need to create automate=
d acceptance tests. Selenium seems to be
> > nice, since it allows someone =
without much (or none at all)
> > programming experience, as our Product Ow=
ner to create those tests
> > with Firefox Selenium IDE plug-in.
> > 
> > B=
ut time has come to integrate those tests to other JUnit tests, so
> > thes=
e can be run on CI server.
> 
> Disclaimer: No JUnit, no Selenium-RC used i=
n the solution below.
> 
> What we did is to put all Selenium tests (HTML s=
ource) in a separate
> web-app, bundled with Selenium Core and an index.jsp=
 that starts the
> test automatically when called by a browser. (We also ma=
ngled Selenium
> Core to let a USERNAME and PASSWORD Selenium variables be =
set and
> present in all tests - mangled means five lines of javascript cod=
e.)
> 
> 
> To have it run in a CI environment ... I wrote two applications=
:
> 
> a) a simple app called "test agent" that can take two commands over
=
> XML-RPC:
> a1) start a browser pointing it at a certain URL (pointing to =
the
> index.jsp file mentioned above, also telling the browser where the
> =
selenium result should be posted)
> a2) stop a browser
> 
> b) A web-app ca=
lled "test conductor" that 
> b1) keeps track of test agents
> b2) aggregat=
e results returned from browsers
> b3) register test new test runs and laun=
ch them when test agents become
> idle
> 
> This works well and having the =
test files in HTML (with human readable
> ID values on all elements the tes=
t interacts with) makes it useful for
> manual testing as well. Since the w=
eb-app with test can be deployed on a
> developers machine, a developer can=
 also ask the test conductor to run a
> test off the developer's machine (a=
nd start debugging server side).
> 
> There's no JUnit integration. We just=
 added a simple script on our CI
> environment (Hudson) that after each suc=
cessful build of the full
> software stack does:
> i) download the build ar=
tifacts, deploy them to a test server
> ii) register a new test run with we=
b-app b mentioned above
> iii) waits for b to return a fail/success
> iv) u=
ndeploys the artifacts from step i
> 
> 
> This was all setup one year ago =
- the client I worked for wasn't sure
> what Selenium could do or if they w=
anted to invest time using it. Having
> the test written/saved in human rea=
dable HTML was a good selling point -
> if they decided to not go with Sele=
nium then the tests could still be
> used "as is".
> 
> Since then:
> Selen=
ium 1.0 still hasn't been released.
> There's still no Selenium Driver that=
 can use HTML files as source.
> 3000+ runs completed.
> We run test agents=
 for FF2, FF3, IE7, Safari on Mac.
> 
> Parts of the test agent and test co=
nductor is BSD-licensed, some parts
> where developed for the client (and I=
 think they'll be happy to share
> under BSD-ish license).
> 
> / Fredrik
